en.simple_stratum_basale_essential: This layer is essential: without it, the skin would not renew itself.
en.simple_stratum_basale_structure: The basal layer is the deepest layer of the epidermis. It is also called 'germinative' because new cells are born here.
en.simple_stratum_basale_single_row: It consists of a single row of cells. They are tall, cylindrical keratinocytes with rich nucleus and cytoplasm.
en.simple_one_stays: One remains in the basal layer
en.simple_one_moves_up: The other moves toward the surface
en.simple_migration_and_maturation: As it moves up, the cell matures and transforms. This process is continuous: the skin renews itself every day.
en.simple_melanocytes_in_basal: Melanocytes are also present in the basal layer.
en.simple_melanocytes_ratio: There is one melanocyte for every 5 or 6 keratinocytes. They produce melanin, the pigment that protects from the sun.
en.spinosum_thickness: The stratum spinosum is the thickest layer of the epidermis. It consists of 4-10 rows of cells.
en.spinosum_cells: The cells are keratinocytes. They have a cuboidal shape and still contain a nucleus.
en.spinosum_projections: They have small spines in the cytoplasm. They are called cytoplasmic projections.
en.spinosum_strength: These spines connect the cells together. They make them stronger and more resistant.
en.spinosum_langerhans: Langerhans cells are also present in this layer.
en.spinosum_immunity: They are immune system cells. They defend the skin from germs and foreign substances.
en.granulosum_flattening: The cells in this layer become increasingly flat. They lose part of the cytoplasm.
en.granulosum_granules: The cytoplasm contains many granules. They contain a substance called keratohyalin.
en.granulosum_keratinization: Keratinization is the process in which cells transform into corneocytes: dead cells that form the stratum corneum.
en.granulosum_barrier: Keratohyalin combines with keratin. It forms a strong, impermeable barrier. It protects the skin from external agents.
en.granulosum_merkel: Merkel cells: for touch and pressure
en.granulosum_merkel_nerves: Merkel cells are connected to nerves. They form Merkel corpuscles, which detect contact.
en.granulosum_nucleus: The cell nucleus begins to weaken. It is a sign that the cell is dying.
en.lucidum_location: The stratum lucidum is very thin. It is present only in thick skin areas: palms of the hands and soles of the feet.
en.lucidum_cells: It consists of 1-2 rows of flattened cells.
en.lucidum_dead: The cells are dead. They have neither nucleus nor cytoplasm.
en.lucidum_appearance: They are translucent and contain a substance called eleidin. Under the microscope, they appear shiny.
en.lucidum_function: Eleidin is an intermediate step in keratin formation.
en.keratogenesis_process: Figure: the keratogenesis process, from birth to death of skin cells.
en.keratin_keratogenesis: Keratin and the process of keratogenesis
en.keratin_protein: Keratin is a strong protein. It is present in skin, nails, hair, and scalp.
en.keratin_structure: It is made of amino acids. They are arranged in a helix shape.
en.cysteine_bridges: The most important amino acid is cysteine. It forms disulfide bridges between keratin fibers. This makes them strong and stable.
en.basal_cell_birth: New cells are born in the basal layer. They form through mitosis.
en.cell_migration: Then they move toward the surface. During their journey:
en.desquamation: On the surface, old cells shed. This process is called desquamation.
en.cell_replacement: One cell is born → one cell dies
en.skin_thickness: The thickness of the skin remains constant
en.turnover_definition: The time to renew the entire epidermis is called turnover.
en.melanin_melanogenesis: Melanin and the process of melanogenesis
en.melanin_skin_hair: Skin and hair color depend on melanin. It is a pigment naturally produced by the body.
en.melanin_tyrosine: Melanin is formed from tyrosine, an amino acid. There are two main types:
en.pheomelanin: Pheomelanin: colors from yellow to red
en.eumelanin: Eumelanin: colors from brown to black
en.eumelanin_uv_protection: Eumelanin offers better protection against UV rays. It reduces the risk of sunburn and DNA damage.
en.light_skin_melanin: Light skin has less melanin. It is less protected from the sun.
en.light_skin_vitamin_d: But it helps produce more vitamin D3. It is important for bones, teeth, the immune system, and hormonal balance.
en.melanocytes_melanogenesis: Melanocytes produce melanin in a process called melanogenesis.
en.melanocytes_location: They are located in the basal layer, among keratinocytes. They have a star shape with many projections.
en.melanosomes: Inside melanocytes are melanosomes. They are small vesicles where melanin is produced and stored.
en.internal_factors: Internal factors: such as hormones (e.g. MSH)
en.sun_exposure_response: When the skin is exposed to the sun:
en.uv_protection: It protects cells from UV rays (UVA and UVB)
en.melanin_natural_filter: Melanin acts as a natural filter for the skin.
en.melanogenesis_figure: Figure: the melanogenesis process. Melanin is formed in melanocytes and transferred to neighboring cells to protect the skin from the sun.
en.dermis_location: The dermis is the layer beneath the epidermis. It is made of strong and elastic connective tissue.
en.dermis_thickness: It is 1-2 mm thick. It performs many functions:
en.papillary_location: It is the layer closest to the epidermis.
en.papillary_papillae: It has small projections: dermal papillae. They interlock with the epidermis and form skin ridges (visible on fingertips).
en.papillary_exchange: They improve the exchange of substances between dermis and epidermis.
en.papillary_structure: It consists of loose connective tissue with:
en.papillary_receptors: Touch receptors (Meissner corpuscles) and cold receptors (Krause corpuscles)
en.middle_dermis_description: Intermediate layer. It has less ground substance than the papillary dermis.
en.reticular_dermis_thickness: It is the thickest layer: it makes up 80% of the dermis.
en.reticular_dermis_strength: It is very resistant, thanks to:
en.reticular_vessels_nerves: It has many large-caliber blood vessels. There are also sensitive nerve endings.
en.reticular_corpuscles: In this layer are the corpuscles:
en.reticular_function: The deep dermis gives strength and elasticity to the skin.
en.reticular_sensation: It also helps perceive heat and pressure thanks to the receptors present.
en.dermis_cell_types: There are several types of cells in the dermis.
en.fibroblasts_function: Fibroblasts produce the fibers and substance that hold the tissue together. Other cell types defend the skin from germs and foreign substances.
en.fibroblasts_abundance: They are the most numerous cells in the dermis. They have a star-like shape.
en.fibroblasts_role: These substances give strength and elasticity to the skin.
en.blood_cells_function: They are white blood cells that enter the dermis during infection or inflammation.
en.macrophages_phagocytosis: They are white blood cells that 'eat' bacteria, dead cells, and foreign substances.
en.macrophages_importance: They are very important for body defense.
en.mast_cells_role: They are defense cells, like sentinels.
en.mast_cells_recognition: They recognize bacteria and foreign substances.
en.mast_cells_inflammation: When they detect danger, they initiate the inflammatory response.
en.immune_cells_summary: Plasma cells, macrophages, and mast cells are part of the immune system.
en.figcaption-content: Figure: the main cells of the dermis. Fibroblasts produce the tissue structure. Other cells protect the skin from external agents.
en.figcaption-fibre: Figure: the fibers of the dermis – collagen and elastin.
en.fibre-desc: There are two main types of fibers in the dermis: collagen and elastic fibers.
en.collagene-abbondanti: They are the most abundant. They make up 70% of the skin's proteins.
en.collagene-forte: They are very strong and resistant. They provide support to the dermis and protect it from tearing.
en.fibre-reticolari: In the superficial dermis, there are also thinner collagen fibers: they are called reticular fibers.
en.elastiche-pochi: They are few: only 2% of the skin's proteins. They are made of a substance called elastin.
en.elasticita-pelle: They give elasticity to the skin. They allow it to:
en.elasticita-lista2: Return to shape after being stretched
en.elasticita-lista3: Adapt to body changes over time
en.collagene-elastina: Collagen and elastin work together: one provides strength, the other elasticity.
en.sostanza-desc: The cells and fibers of the dermis are immersed in a gelatinous substance. It is called ground substance or matrix.
en.sostanza-prodotta: It is produced by fibroblasts. It gives flexibility and plasticity to the skin.
en.composizione-utili: Glucose, salts, vitamins, and ions – useful substances for cells
en.composizione-gag: Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) – including hyaluronic acid, the most abundant
en.gag-desc: GAGs are long sugar chains. They have an important characteristic:
en.gag-acqua: They retain a lot of water. They form a gel similar to a wet sponge.
en.fase-dispersa: GAG molecules are the dispersed phase (the network)
en.fase-disperdente: Water is the dispersing phase (fills the spaces)
en.gel-importanza: This gel occupies almost all the space between dermal cells. It is very important because:
en.turgore: It makes the skin firm and plump (skin turgor)
en.figcaption-ipoderma: Figure: structure of the hypodermis, also known as subcutaneous tissue.
en.ipoderma-desc1: The hypodermis is the deepest layer of the skin. It lies beneath the dermis. It is also called subcutaneous tissue.
en.ipoderma-adiposo: It is made mostly of adipose tissue. Fat cells are called adipocytes.
en.protegge: Protects: acts as a cushion against impacts and trauma
en.collega: Connects: anchors the skin to underlying tissues (muscles and bones)
en.ipoderma-desc2: It extends to the tissue covering the muscles. It is made of adipose connective tissue, rich in fat cells: adipocytes.
en.riserva-energia: Energy reserve: adipocytes store fats useful when the body needs them
en.protezione-meccanica: Mechanical protection: acts as a shock absorber against impacts and trauma
en.modellamento-corpo: Body shaping: gives form and aesthetic appearance
en.spessore-ipoderma: The thickness of the hypodermis varies from person to person. It depends on age, sex, nutrition, and genetics.
en.figcaption-adiposo: Figure: comparison between white and brown adipose tissue.
en.adiposo-bianco-comune: It is the most common. It represents almost all the body's reserve fat.
en.goccia-grasso: One large fat droplet inside the cell
en.bruno-piccole-gocce: Brown adipose tissue has many small fat droplets inside the cell. The nucleus is in the center.
en.ricco-mitocondri: It is rich in mitochondria, the cell's 'powerhouses'. It also has many blood vessels.
en.funzione-calore: Its main function is heat production. It helps maintain body temperature.
en.localizzazione-neonati: In newborns, it is found mainly in:
en.trasformazione: As we grow, most brown tissue turns into white tissue.
en.adulti-bruno: In adults, brown tissue is present only in small amounts. It forms small islands among white fat cells.
en.tessuti-misti: There are no pure deposits of a single type. Adipose tissues are always mixed. The percentage depends on the body location.
en.pelle-sente: The skin senses through a dense network of nerves.
en.recettori-specializzati: It contains many specialized receptors. They detect different stimuli and send them to the brain.
en.sensazioni: The brain transforms them into sensations such as:
en.recettore-stimolo: Each receptor responds to a different type of stimulus.
en.figcaption-recettori: Figure: the main nerve receptors present in the skin.
